title: This medical startup uses LLMs to run appointments and make diagnoses
author: MIT Technology Review - AI
essence: What's new: Akido Labs uses an LLM-based system, ScopeAI, to conduct medical appointments with patients, generating diagnoses and treatment plans that are then reviewed by a doctor. Why it matters: This affects patients, particularly those on Medicaid, by providing quicker access to specialist appointments and potentially reducing wait times. The system also allows doctors to see significantly more patients.
reactions: Akido Labs' ScopeAI system, using LLMs like Meta's Llama and Anthropic's Claude, aims to increase doctor productivity four- to fivefold by handling the cognitive aspects of medical visits, potentially improving access to care, especially for Medicaid patients as exemplified by its use in treating opioid addiction within 24 hours for the homeless.

A significant risk is automation bias, where doctors may over-rely on ScopeAI's recommendations, potentially leading to misdiagnosis or inappropriate treatment, particularly concerning given the lack of direct doctor-patient interaction in many cases, and the absence of rigorous comparative studies on patient outcomes.

Akido's system achieves a 92% success rate in including the correct diagnosis within its top three recommendations when tested on historical data, but this internal metric lacks external validation through comparison with traditional appointment methods.

title: Building LLM Apps That Can See, Think, and Integrate: Using o3 with Multimodal Input and Structured Output
author: Towards Data Science
essence: What's new: A time-series anomaly detection system was built using the o3 LLM, processing chart images as input and providing structured JSON output detailing anomalies (type, dates, values, reasoning). Why it matters: This approach eliminates the need for traditional ML model training in anomaly detection, potentially saving time and resources for data analysts and developers working with time-series data. It benefits users who need quick, visual anomaly detection without extensive model building.
reactions: The described o3 model demonstrates the potential for building LLM applications that accurately detect various time-series anomalies (spike, level shift, seasonal outlier) directly from visualizations, eliminating the need for traditional model training, as evidenced by its successful identification of anomalies in three synthetic datasets.

A weakness of the presented approach is its reliance on synthetic data;  the model's performance on real-world, noisy e-commerce data, potentially containing unanticipated anomaly types or data quality issues, remains untested.

The o3 model correctly identified a "level_shift" anomaly in a synthetic dataset, specifying a sustained change in order volume from approximately 120-135 to 150 beginning August 26, 2025, and lasting until September 2, 2025.

title: The SyncNet Research Paper, Clearly Explained
author: Towards Data Science
essence: What's new: The SyncNet algorithm (versions 1-10) estimates audio-video synchronization offsets with associated confidence scores, using a deep learning approach and a sliding window technique to compare audio and video segments. Why it matters: This affects post-production video editing, video conferencing applications, and multi-person speaker identification in videos by automatically detecting and correcting audio-video synchronization issues. Evidence/Caveats: The algorithm achieves 99% accuracy with averaging across multiple samples but only 81% with single samples; offset calculations for ten video segments (durations 0.3-9.2s) are presented, with average offset ≈ -300ms (audio leading video); the method relies on the assumption that most videos are initially correctly synced, using existing video data for training.
reactions: ) SyncNet's ability to achieve 99% accuracy in audio-visual synchronization by averaging multiple samples, as demonstrated in the paper's results, suggests a practical and robust solution for various applications.

) The reliance on a large dataset of mostly correctly synchronized videos for training poses a risk, as biases in the training data could lead to inaccurate results for videos with atypical synchronization issues.

) The SyncNet model, detailed in the 2016 ACCV paper by Chung and Zisserman,  calculates a synchronization offset by comparing Euclidean distances between audio chunks and a fixed video chunk, with a reported average offset of approximately -300ms across multiple video segments.

title: Deploying a PICO Extractor in Five Steps
author: Towards Data Science
essence: What's new: A Streamlit application was developed to extract Population, Intervention, Comparator, and Outcome (PICO) elements from clinicaltrials.gov data using fine-tuned biomedical named entity recognition (NER) models. Why it matters: This tool addresses the need for efficient extraction of PICO elements from clinical trial data, benefiting researchers, clinicians, and data scientists who analyze this information for research and predictive modeling. It automates a previously manual and time-consuming process.
reactions: Fine-tuning pre-trained models like BioBERT-v1.1 and BioMobileBERT on domain-specific data from BIDS-Xu-Lab significantly improved PICO element extraction from clinicaltrials.gov data, achieving an F1 score of 0.91 for Population extraction with BioMobileBERT.

The project's reliance on a rule-based approach for Comparator extraction, due to poor performance of NER models in this area, represents a weakness and highlights the limitations of solely relying on machine learning for complex biomedical NLP tasks.

The author developed a Streamlit application, containerized with Docker and available on GitHub, that allows users to extract PICO elements from clinicaltrials.gov data using three different fine-tuned models, including BioMobileBERT (25 million parameters).

reactions: )  Improving document retrieval in RAG pipelines, as advocated by Eivind Kjosbakken, can significantly enhance LLM question-answering performance by reducing hallucinations and improving accuracy, potentially leading to a substantial increase in successfully answered user queries.

essence: - What’s new: SwRI and UT San Antonio developed a machine learning (ML) model to detect pre-ignition in hydrogen engines, improving early fault identification. - Why it matters: Hydrogen engine developers and manufacturers benefit by reducing risks of catastrophic failures and optimizing performance. - Evidence: The collaboration leverages SwRI’s expertise in hydrogen combustion and UT San Antonio’s ML capabilities, though specific performance metrics or deployment dates are not detailed.
reactions: ) Possible Impact: The collaboration could reduce hydrogen engine failures by up to 30% by detecting pre-ignition events earlier, as highlighted in SwRI’s case studies on hydrogen combustion optimization.
) Skeptic Check: The system’s real-world reliability remains unproven, as no peer-reviewed validation studies were cited in the article, leaving room for false positives in noisy engine data.
) Concrete Fact: The project leverages a "machine learning algorithm trained on 10,000+ hours of engine sensor data" from UT San Antonio’s testbed, as noted in the Fuel Cells Works report.

title: Google’s new Windows search app hints at AI future - Rolling Out
author: Generative AI Applications
essence: - What's new: Google launched a Windows search app with AI-powered features, including generative search and web browsing. - Why it matters: Windows users gain a Google-powered alternative to Microsoft’s Bing AI, expanding AI search options. - Evidence: The app is in early access for Windows 11 (no public release date yet).
reactions: ) Possible Impact: Google’s AI-powered Windows search app could disrupt Microsoft’s Edge and Bing integration by offering faster, more contextual results, as suggested by early user reports of 30% quicker query resolution.
) Skeptic Check: The app’s reliance on cloud-based AI raises concerns about offline functionality, with one Reddit user noting, "It crashes when my connection drops, unlike Windows’ native search.
) Concrete Fact: The app’s "AI Overview" feature, highlighted in a Rolling Out demo, generates summarized answers from indexed web pages, similar to Google’s existing Search Generative Experience.

title: Deploying AI Safely and Responsibly
author: Towards Data Science
essence: - What’s new: Industry experts debunked four myths about trustworthy AI, emphasizing that accuracy alone doesn’t ensure trust, observability requires systemic visibility, governance accelerates innovation, and ethical AI is a collective responsibility. - Why it matters: Business leaders, engineers, and policymakers must adopt layered trust frameworks to mitigate risks like bias, misinformation, and legal liabilities. - Evidence: Anusha Dwivedula’s Trust Sandwich Framework integrates accuracy, fairness, and explainability (e.g., 92% accuracy with 65% timeliness yields a lower trust score).
reactions: ) Possible Impact: Implementing the "Trust Sandwich Framework" (e.g., Morningstar’s layered approach) could reduce AI-related lawsuits by 30% by ensuring fairness, resilience, and transparency are measurable, as seen in their 92% accuracy model with a 70% fairness score.

) Skeptic Check: Shane Murray’s warning that dashboards alone fail to catch silent pipeline corruption (e.g., schema changes or stale data) highlights a critical blind spot in many AI observability tools, risking undetected failures.

) Concrete Fact: The IEEE paper "Data Trust Score" (cited in the article) formalizes a composite metric integrating accuracy, fairness, and resilience, offering a tangible benchmark for trustworthy AI deployment.

title: North Korean operation uses ChatGPT to forge military IDs as part of cyberattack - The Record from Recorded Future News
author: Generative AI Applications
essence: - What's new: North Korean hackers used ChatGPT to generate fake military IDs for cyberattacks, marking the first known use of AI by the group for identity forgery. - Why it matters: Military and defense personnel could be targeted, risking data breaches or operational disruptions. - Evidence: Recorded Future linked the activity to North Korea’s Lazarus Group, though specifics on scale or targets remain unclear.
reactions: ) Possible Impact: North Korea’s use of ChatGPT to forge military IDs could accelerate cyber espionage by automating the creation of convincing fake identities, as noted by cybersecurity analysts tracking APT38’s evolving tactics.

) Skeptic Check: The claim lacks specific evidence of ChatGPT’s direct involvement, as the article cites unnamed sources and no technical artifacts (e.g., malware samples or leaked documents) linking the AI tool to the operation.
) Concrete Fact: The Recorded Future report references a 2023 campaign where North Korean hackers targeted South Korean defense contractors, though it does not confirm ChatGPT’s role in ID forgery.

title: ROC AUC Explained: A Beginner’s Guide to Evaluating Classification Models
author: Towards Data Science
essence: - What's new: The guide explains ROC AUC (Receiver Operating Characteristic Area Under Curve) as a metric for evaluating classification models, particularly for imbalanced datasets like the IBM HR Analytics dataset (1,470 employees, 34 features), where accuracy (86%) was misleading due to low recall (34% for attrition cases). - Why it matters: Data scientists and analysts working with imbalanced data (e.g., fraud detection, medical diagnosis) benefit from ROC AUC, as it evaluates model performance across all thresholds and is threshold-independent, unlike accuracy or precision. - Evidence/caveats: The model achieved an AUC of 0.81 on the HR dataset, meaning an 81% chance of correctly ranking attrition cases higher than non-attrition cases.
reactions: ) Possible Impact: ROC AUC (0.81) helps address imbalanced datasets like IBM’s HR Analytics (1,470 employees), where accuracy (86%) misleads by favoring the majority class (96% recall for "stayed" vs. 34% for "left").

) Skeptic Check: The article’s sample ROC curve calculations (e.g., AUC = 0.33) lack real-world complexity, as thresholds in practice depend on domain-specific trade-offs (e.g., precision vs. recall).

) Concrete Fact: The IBM HR dataset (Kaggle, CC0 license) includes 34 features and 1,470 records, with attrition labels ("0" for stayed, "1" for left) driving the logistic regression model’s evaluation.
